Now we need to do the same for this set. (After that we need to do the same for form 3P)

The filing ids for the 366 filings available through /filings/ but not /reports/ are in the document below:
missing_filings.txt

To resolve this issue, we need to:

  - [ ] create new view that includes F3 plus F3X submitted by House and senate committees
  - [ ] API work to use the new view
  - [ ] test
@hcaofec @pkfec @jwchumley

Continues work at #3038 and #3103

title: Schedule A aggregate by state incorrect
body:
Thank you @fecjjeng and @ChingKuan for catching this!

`ofec_sched_a_aggregate_state_recipient_totals_mv` is joining on "state = fips code", resulting in the /schedule_a/by_state/totals/ endpoint returning incorrect results: https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/schedules/schedule_a/by_state/totals/?sort=cycle&per_page=20&api_key=DEMO_KEY&page=1


```
WHERE (agg_st.state::text IN (SELECT fips_state_code
                   FROM staging.ref_zip_to_district))
``` 

should be (typo is in the table)

```
WHERE (agg_st.state::text IN (SELECT **state_abbrevation**
                   FROM staging.ref_zip_to_district))
``` 
- [x] make a new migration for `ofec_sched_a_aggregate_state_recipient_totals_mv`

title: Research: Investigate possible bug in /schedules/schedule_a/ - compare data to line totals on report
body:
Attempting to verify line item contributions pulled using /schedules/schedule_a/ match totals.
(https://github.com/fecgov/openFEC/blob/develop/data/functions/individual.sql) for defining individual contributions.

- [ ] Documentation suggests items where `"is_individual": true` should equal totals, though this is either incomplete, bugging, or both.

Example: Will Hurd's total itemized individual contributions is reported as $566,211.43. After paginating through the [full query](https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/schedules/schedule_a/?committee_id=C00545467&committee_id=C00470351&is_individual=TRUE&api_key=DEMO_KEY&per_page=100) and combining the results, filtering on `is_individual` alone gives a `contributions_receipt_amount` sum of ~$1,396,410. Filtering on `is_individual` and `memo_code` gives a sum of ~$564,211. 

Downloading the [itemized individual contributions manually](https://www.fec.gov/data/receipts/?committee_id=C00545467&two_year_transaction_period=2018&cycle=2018&line_number=F3-11AI&data_type=processed), filtering on `memo_code` alone gives the correct sum. Filtering on both `memo_code` and `is_individual` comes up $2,000 short. The `contribution_id` of the items with potential issues are SA11AI.27345 and SA11AI.28956, both of which seem to involve `entity_type` ORG -> IND without a `memo_code` update.

This is a research ticket to determine what's up with "is_individual": true`

title: Count estimate for receipts search approximately doubles the amount returned
body:
What we are after: 
More accurate estimates or precise counts of transactions.

Why we are after it: 
The current estimates mislead users. They can think their downloaded file is incomplete. 

Competition criteria: 
- [x] Research using `explain analyze=True` but need to figure out if this impacts performance. Use `pgBadger` to analyze. Analyzed number may give a better estimate of the counts. https://github.com/fecgov/openFEC/blob/develop/webservices/common/counts.py#L32
- [ ] Inventory everywhere on the front end where the counts are being pulled in. Each pulls from a different end point and they may be broken.
- [ ] Schedule a meeting to talk about this
- [ ] Investigate reinstating the manifest file with a better design
- [ ] fix the estimate

https://www.fec.gov/data/receipts/?two_year_transaction_period=2018&data_type=processed&committee_id=C00000935&min_date=01%2F01%2F2017&max_date=05%2F01%2F2018&contributor_state=IL

This example returns 18,963 rows but the estimate shows 41,000. [7/2/2018]

This is an annoyance and it makes people think they haven't downloaded all of the rows they want.

title: /filings/ endpoint marking more than one `most_recent` Form 1 (Statement of Organization)
body:
- [ ] Add a testing ticket

So that committees and the public can see the most recent version of the Form 1 (Statement of Organization), we need to update the logic to handle when a committee files multiple Form 1's as new and only show the newest as "Current Version" and the others as "Past Version."

@patphongs discovered this issue.

Example: (https://www.fec.gov/data/committee/C00639013/?tab=filings)

![8-31-2017 3-35-01 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31420082/29941933-2965589e-8e62-11e7-9e47-56b989cdba16.jpg)

Background: Using FECFile and other 3rd party vendors, committees can amend their Statement of Organization (Form 1) by filing it as new. Then, an overnight process updates it to show as amended. As a result, there is no amendment number associated with the file that was submitted as new and now displays as amended.

Potential fix: Add to /filings/ "amendment chain" logic to handle multiple F1Ns for the same committee.  If the amendment chain logic fails (>1 current version for the same filing type - for statements of org. ) then use the most recently filed one as the current version and mark the others as past version.

- [X] F2 also has the same issue? Find an example to confirm
API example
https://fec-dev-api.app.cloud.gov/v1/filings/?api_key=DEMO_KEY&sort_hide_null=false&sort=-receipt_date&per_page=10&page=1&candidate_id=H8CA05035&form_type=F99&form_type=RFAI&request_type=-1&request_type=-2&request_type=-3&request_type=-4&request_type=-5&request_type=-6&request_type=-7&request_type=-8&request_type=-9
Other front-end example:
https://fec-dev-proxy.app.cloud.gov/data/candidate/H8WI01024/?tab=filings
~- [ ] Run the PGtap amendment chain test (#3268)~ PGTap test is for efiling amendment_chain
- [X] Write a new python test that fails for current behavior
- [X] modify F1 (and F2?) function logic for amendments -- create special case for committees that file multiple  Form 1 "New"s.



Existing amendment chain view is complicated and not a good place to fix the logic for F1's and F2's. We should investigate where else we can fix the logic upstream.

title: Optimize IE queries
body:
@AmyKort commented on [Tue Dec 05 2017](https://github.com/fecgov/fec-cms/issues/1614)

The filters on the independent expenditure search appear not to be working. We've concluded that this behavior is a result of a performance issue, where a 500 error being thrown almost immediately for one of the underlying API calls:

https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/schedules/schedule_e/?sort_hide_null=true&data_type=processed&committee_id=C30001911&committee_id=C90013244&cycle=2014&is_notice=false&sort=-expenditure_date&per_page=30
And as described, if you look at the page, the 2013 - 2014 choice in the Years filter is behaving as if it is still waiting for a response.

The ability to search and filter IEs is an important tool for users wanting to better understand campaign spending, so fixing this bug is a top priority.

Original identification of the problem:

@rshorey commented on [Thu Nov 30 2017](https://github.com/18F/FEC/issues/4782)

I added a bunch of filters to the independent expenditure search, but it appears to be showing me everything. I tried on multiple browsers (including one that won't have any cached visits to FEC sites)

Here's the URL:
https://www.fec.gov/data/independent-expenditures/?data_type=processed&committee_id=C30001911&committee_id=C90013244&cycle=2014&is_notice=false

here's a screenshot of it showing my filters and then showing a bunch of unrelated results:
![screen shot 2017-11-30 at 12 13 10 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/901091/33444463-61e9d3a4-d5c8-11e7-8db8-0f8bc4a97d57.png)

Thanks!

---

@LindsayYoung commented on [Thu Nov 30 2017](https://github.com/18F/FEC/issues/4782#issuecomment-348279477)

thanks for reporting @rshorey!



---

@jwchumley commented on [Wed Dec 13 2017](https://github.com/fecgov/fec-cms/issues/1614#issuecomment-351477638)

I think this is a performance issue @LindsayYoung @ccostino. If you click on the link:
https://www.fec.gov/data/independent-expenditures/?data_type=processed&committee_id=C30001911&committee_id=C90013244&cycle=2014&is_notice=false

It seems to show everything but I think it's hanging up because the 2013-2014 filter is still cycling like it isn't done. 

If you deselect the two committees and the cycle then try selecting them again you can't select them all without a message saying "We had trouble processing your request
Please try again. If you still have trouble, let us know"

@ccostino commented on [Fri Dec 15 2017](https://github.com/fecgov/fec-cms/issues/1614#issuecomment-352089314)

@LindsayYoung, now that I think about this more I have a sneaking suspicion given the behavior that we might be missing an index(es) on one of the columns or we need a multicolumn index(es) similar to what we had to do with schedule A and B to account for the sorting and paging.

---

@ccostino commented on [Fri Dec 15 2017](https://github.com/fecgov/fec-cms/issues/1614#issuecomment-352090807)

Here are the current indexes on `ofec_sched_e` for reference:

```
Indexes:
    "ofec_sched_e_sub_id_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (sub_id)
    "idx_ofec_sched_e_cal_ytd_ofc_sought_sub_id" btree (cal_ytd_ofc_sought, sub_id)
    "idx_ofec_sched_e_cmte_id" btree (cmte_id)

    "idx_ofec_sched_e_entity_tp" btree (entity_tp)

    "idx_ofec_sched_e_image_num" btree (image_num)
    "idx_ofec_sched_e_is_notice" btree (is_notice)
    "idx_ofec_sched_e_payee_name_text" gin (payee_name_text)
    "idx_ofec_sched_e_pg_date" btree (pg_date)
    "idx_ofec_sched_e_rpt_yr" btree (rpt_yr)

```

@PaulClark2 commented on [Sun Feb 04 2018](https://github.com/fecgov/fec-cms/issues/1614#issuecomment-362954246)

title: Research Paper filings missing from API /reports/ and /filings/
body:
At least 591 paper filings available from the bulk downloads seem to be missing from the API's /reports/ endpoint: when we fetch a /reports/ endpoint for a committee, the response does not include any records with these filing ids in the file_number field. 366 of those filings are accessible through the /filings/ endpoint. It seems that the filings which are available through /filings/ but not /reports/ show up on the website, but the summary fields for those are shown as $0 regardless of the filing's actual content.

The filing ids for the 366 filings available through /filings/ but not /reports/ are in the document below:
[missing_filings.txt](https://github.com/fecgov/openFEC/files/1860896/missing_filings.txt)

title: [MERGE WITH GIT FLOW] Hotfix: Change celery task to check for just modified MURs
body:
Celery-worker checks every 15 minutes to see if there are any MURs modified in the past day. However, the query for modified MURs wasn't properly filtering for just MURs. As a result, when AF/ADR cases were updated, MURs were reloaded starting with that number. When it was a low number, *all* MURs ended up getting reloaded, causing significant resource problems.

This PR updates the `RECENTLY_MODIFIED_STARTING_MUR` query to filter for just `case_type='MUR'`

Noting here, there's a related issue that I'd like to tackle this sprint: #2646

title: Fix zipcode search - limit match to left(5) of parameter value.
body:
See related cms issue: https://github.com/fecgov/fec-cms/issues/1391

When a 9-digit zip is passed to the `/schedules/schedule_a/` endpoint, we should truncate it to 5 characters. Not all filers report 9-digit zips, so searching by zip+4 returns unreliable data. In addition, currently searching by 5-digit zips is excluding records that have 9-digit zips. Also, we should add some automated tests to test_itemized to confirm this behavior. 

- [ ] `schedule_a.py` - match the  inputted zip value to left 5 characters to the left(5) of `contributor_zip` column to  in the `ScheduleA` model - do this in the resource with `if kwargs.get('contributor_zip'):...`
- [ ] `test_itemized.py` - add some automated tests for zip+4 searches

Should all schedules work this way? only the ones that search by zip. Maybe next look at `ScheduleAByZip` - looks like it doesn't return results when you pass +4.
https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/schedules/schedule_a/by_zip/?api_key=DEMO_KEY&zip=200162409&page=1&per_page=20

**Example**

title: Fix retrieval of application space name in cloud.gov for Redis retries
body:
This changeset addresses another issue with the Redis retries:  [`py-cfenv`](https://github.com/jmcarp/py-cfenv/) only pulls credentials from `VCAP_SERVICES`; the space name (and a few other things) come from `VCAP_APPLICATION` and are exposed differently.

Additional comments explaining what is happening in the method have also been added.

title: Attempt to fix Redis connection retries
body: This changeset attempts to fix an issue we are running into with our Redis connection retry adjustment.  At the very least it provides more logging to give insight into where the breakdown might be (or could be in the future), but a couple of the checks have been adjusted to be more explicit and might help alleviate the issue as well.  If not, we will continue to monitor and adjust, but we will need to get this running in the cloud.gov environment to see.

title: Change exclude logic to return null values
body:
Change "exclude" filter logic in API to return null values. For example, searching for request_type !=2 should return all other request_types as well as records without a request_type.

@patphongs is working the missing RFAI issue and attempting to use the new API exclusion capability. She found that nulls are being excluded from the call. She added the ability to also filter by request_type on her local API, so that’s what she's working on trying to exclude. Here’s an example:

This particular call is asking for a bunch of form_types: http://localhost:5000/v1/committee/C00637983/filings/?api_key=DEMO_KEY&sort_hide_null=false&sort=-coverage_end_date&sort=report_type_full&sort=-beginning_image_number&per_page=100&page=1&form_type=F3&form_type=F3X&form_type=F3P&form_type=F3L&form_type=F4&form_type=F7&form_type=F13&form_type=RFAI&cycle=2018

This is asking for the same form_types as above with the addition of excluding request_type 2. http://localhost:5000/v1/committee/C00637983/filings/?api_key=DEMO_KEY&sort_hide_null=false&sort=-coverage_end_date&sort=report_type_full&sort=-beginning_image_number&per_page=100&page=1&form_type=F3&form_type=F3X&form_type=F3P&form_type=F3L&form_type=F4&form_type=F7&form_type=F13&form_type=RFAI&request_type=-2&cycle=2018

The latter call should return everything from the former call, excluding records with request_type 2, which should only be 1 record excluded. But it’s returning only records of request_type 1, meaning it removed all records with request_type null. We need a way to filter without excluding nulls. There’s not really any way to handle nulls right now as inclusion or exclusion criteria (i.e. return values that are null, exclude values but include null).

- [x] Add automated tests

title: Required API parameters are not marked as required in rest.py
body:
So that users get the data they need from the API, required API parameters should be marked as `required` in Swagger.

 For example, the /elections/ endpoint requires office and will throw a 422 error if it's not provided. Office should be marked `required=true` in `rest.py`. This is further complicated by the fact that we're currently unable to display 422 errors - they're showing as 500 errors. See issue https://github.com/18F/openFEC/issues/2962

- [ ] Make sure required API parameters are marked as required in rest.py
 - cycle and office in /elections/ for example

title: [MERGE WITH GIT FLOW] Fixed refresh materialized management method
body:
**PLEASE MERGE WITH GIT FLOW**

Fixes #2829

This changeset fixes an issue that we uncovered with the latest production deployment, where the nightly updates had partially failed due to materialized views not being refreshed properly.  The cause was because the `db.session` object was being used instead of the `db.engine` object, which in turn made the queries go through the custom router we have setup instead of connecting directly to the master database.

title: Fix management, nightly update, and related commands to always run against master DB
body:
We uncovered an issue with the most recent production deployment that showed the updates were actually running against the read replicas, which we do not want.  Anything of that nature, be it the nightly update tasks, other management commands, etc., always needs to run against the master database, not the read replicas.

The problem stems from the fact that the [custom DB routing session](https://github.com/18F/openFEC/blob/develop/webservices/common/models/base.py#L8-L44) we have, which manages the connection to the database before any query is executed, will always randomly select a follower by default as long as the follower connection string(s) is/are set.  In the case of production these are set with the two read replicas we have, so the updates have likely been executing against a follower the entire time.

I'm not entirely sure why the other statements would have worked in the past while the `REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW [CONCURRENTLY]` wouldn't, but that's what tipped us off as we're now able to refresh the materialized views directly again instead of rebuilding them with the recent DB migration work.  I confirmed this by running the code locally, printing out which connection was being used in the router, and stepping through the code in the refresh task to see the connection info.

In order to fix this, we need to adjust the DB routing so that it always points to master in the case of management commands, regardless of whether or not the are run manually or automatically via Celery.  Compounding this a bit is the fact that the `celery-worker` we have running accesses the same user-provided credentials as the main API app, which means that it also sees the read replica connection strings set and would therefore use them.

My recommendation would be to fix this in the routing code itself as much as possible (though it will likely require some adjustments in the calls being made, too, e.g., the `refresh_materialized` task) and as a hot fix, otherwise production updates will fall behind very quickly and require manual updates each night/morning until this is fixed.

title: Reinstate nightly refreshes for schedule E data
body:
Fixes #2813

This changeset adds support for schedule E nightly refreshes back into place.  The recent migration work accidentally removed the nightly refresh support for schedule E.

A huge h/t to @vrajmohan and @LindsayYoung for helping test and uncover this issue!

title: Reinstate nightly updates for schedule E data
body:
The recent work with the migrations did have one side effect:  we lost the nightly updates to schedule E.  That last bit of work around this had us removing all queue processing for schedule E and just [rebuilding the table each night](https://github.com/18F/openFEC/blob/master/webservices/tasks/refresh.py#L22) with the [table creation setup](https://github.com/18F/openFEC/blob/master/data/sql_setup/prepare_schedule_e.sql).

The `update_itemized` method was removed, though, and the table creation slightly modified with the migration work.  We'll have to devise a new way to make this refresh possible again.

title: Statutory citations are sometimes repeated in a single AO
body: If you look at the statutory citations for https://www.fec.gov/data/legal/advisory-opinions/2012-36/, you will see repetitions. Although there is code to prevent this kind of repetition (similar code is used to prevent repetitions in regulatory citations), it is not working correctly for statutory citations. Thanks to @lbeaufort for catching this. We eliminate duplicates by storing the citations in a `set` data structure. In addition to the title and section of the citation, we store the text where the citation occurs, and the _former_ titles and sections (to deal with reclassifications of sections) as shown below: ``` "statutory_citations": [ { "former_section": 431, "former_title": 2, "section": 30101, "text": "2 U.S.C. 431(15) and 11 CFR 100.14(a). ", "title": 52 }, { "former_section": 431, "former_title": 2, "section": 30101, "text": "2 U.S.C. 431(2); 11 CFR ", "title": 52 }, { "former_section": 431, "former_title": 2, "section": 30101, "text": "2 U.S.C. 431(15); 11 CFR 100.14(a). ", "title": 52 } ] ``` My suspicion is that these additional fields are different. In the UI, as we only need the current title and section, we should eliminate these extraneous fields. This approach should be verified to ensure that we do not need these additional fields.

Statute: `(?P<title>\d+)\s+U\.?S\.?C\.?\s+§*\s*(?P<section>\d+).*\.?`
Regulation: `(?P<title>\d+)\s+C\.?F\.?R\.?\s+§*\s*(?P<part>\d+)\.(?P<section>\d+)`

Added tests to confirm this worked

title: Fix and improve update_all process
body:
The `update_all` process, which resets all of the API-based tables and views/materialized views, hasn't run fully for us since the last few changes made to it.  We are currently investigating why this is as we need to be able to run it to keep the database schemas up to date as substantial changes are made, such as the schedule A and B refactoring we have been working on recently.

As of now, we've broken apart some of the scripts that are executed to get a bit more visibility into what's being run when and some additional logging, but more adjustments are on the way as we continue to investigate.

title: Remove nightly refresh of schedule A and B in prod
body:
This changeset is intended to alleviate an immediate problem we are facing in prod with record inserts.  This work was already completed in the development branch with #2589 and tested in that environment and has had the desired and positive impact we were looking for.  The situation in prod is becoming worse and we cannot wait for the next release for this to be fixed, hence this hotfix.

This hotfix also addresses the broken tests and dependency adjustments we had made and tested in `develop`.  In addition to ensuring this hotfix has passing tests and can be deployed successfully to production, this will also fix the automatic deploys that we have setup to refresh the application.

title: Tweak Celery config to flip ack_late setting
body:
This changeset flips the [`ack_late`](http://docs.celeryproject.org/en/latest/reference/celery.app.task.html#celery.app.task.Task.acks_late) (`task_acks_late` in the config code) setting to be `False` again due to some strange behavior we are seeing in the dev environment.  Tasks occasionally get run twice and at the moment this appears to be the only culprit.  The documentation in Celery clearly states that if a worker crashes while processing the task will be run again, but we are not seeing a crash when a task has run more than once.

While this may help the issue, we should continue investigating to see if tasks are being redelivered to the workers as that can also cause this to happen.  It seems that the [`celery flower`](http://docs.celeryproject.org/en/latest/userguide/monitoring.html?highlight=celery%20flower) monitoring tool is a potential culprit in that case but again, it is unclear in our case.

More information can be found in this [user group thread](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/celery-users/W0Qf09ahjas/FgVWqrefkAcJ) describing very similar behavior.

When looking at the logs, I did not see multiple `task_received` messages for the `refresh` task.

**MORE DETAILS**

When looking at the cloud.gov `celery-worker` logs for `dev` this morning after seeing this happen again, I noticed that the Main Process received the `refresh` task, kicked off a worker process, worker 1 in this case, and worker 1 seemed to restart itself shortly after kicking off - that or the logs displayed something out of order.

I never saw a line for Worker 2 starting the process, it just seemed to randomly pick up at updating aggregates and Schedule E.

Both workers then finished the processing and as we saw, sent emails after success.

title: Nightly refresh process failing/not working correctly in the dev environment
body:
We have been having some issues with the nightly processing in our development environment:

* Status emails haven't been going out
* Queries are getting locked up in the database
* The nightly refresh job has hung up and doesn't fully complete
* Celery sometimes doesn't get shut down gracefully and throws a small stack trace
* The nightly retry processing for schedule A and B data is still causing issues

I've been doing a lot of digging around this morning into the issues we've been having with the `dev` database and I'm reaching a couple of conclusions:  the extra nightly retry processing I had tried to put in place to catch records that we couldn't initially process with the schedule A and B queues appears to be causing far more problems than it is helping anything, and what happens if our nightly refresh ends up in a state where it's still running at the point it gets triggered again the next day (this should never be the case, it takes 1 - 2 hours at most to run on average).

Some extra context into things:

We started noticing these issues around July 29th.  I'm still not sure what ultimately started causing the deadlocks and row contention with the aggregate processing, but that's when the errors start getting reported (looking into the cloud.gov logs of the `dev` `celery-worker` app).  These ultimately culminate in the emails never getting sent out and a Mandrill (the email processing app we use) max retry error to be thrown, hence the lack of emails being sent out for `dev` from the nightly update bot we have setup.

Another thing to note:  even with the nightly processing itself shut off (we had done this as a hotfix recently), the triggers are still active, and I'm seeing errors in the RDS logs with duplicate keys trying to be inserted (even though we have code to remove existing records with matching keys first before inserting!).  Potentially due to these,  I've noticed some EOF and connection timeout errors too in the Celery worker logs.

Updating Celery in `dev` in prep for our next release seems like a good idea as there are a host of bug fixes in it, and I have caught several times when it throws a small stack trace when it shuts down, which may leave jobs in an unstable state.  `staging` and `prod` seem to be okay and have been updating fine each night, but they're still running on the 3.x series of Celery.

We also had the Redis connectivity issue early this week too, compounding a bit of this but not a direct cause (the initial errors happened a few days before).

Back to the problem at hand:

The main problem is the aggregate updates, those have gotten hung up in dev due to deadlocked processes when they attempt to run (and generally get stuck on the very first step, updating zip codes for schedule A).

Because the processes get locked, the main nightly refresh task doesn't quite "finish" despite having thrown some success messages - the underlying update aggregate queries are still active and locked in the DB.

For some reason despite reporting itself as having finished, the refresh task/job is still in a pending state of sorts so no email is sent out and eventually causes the email code to throw an error of max retries being hit.

As soon as I kill these processes/locked queries in the DB that should free things up and finally finish the tasks.  This was the case the last time we ran into this, and shutting off the nightly retry processing alleviated the issue in `staging` and `prod`.  It appears something is still not quite right with `dev`, and the Celery version is the main difference in that respect.  The recent update might help alleviate some issues.

Next steps:

* [x] Submit a PR to update Celery in `dev`
* [x] Submit a PR to rip out all remaining nightly retry processing - it has caused more problems than it is has helped solve
* [ ] Begin work on next phase of schedule A and B refactoring to focus on keep track of record updates and improving/removing the original queue processing (will work with @vrajmohan on this - tracked by #2423)
* [ ] Potentially add support to detect an already running nightly refresh job and kill it before starting a new one, despite this being a situation that should not happen (thanks, @jontours, for talking through this)

title: Fix tests with references to the unittest.mock module
body:
This changeset addresses an issue that was uncovered shortly after the updates to the development requirements.  I had not cleaned out my virtual environment entirely and therefore still had the existing backport `mock` library in it, which prevented me from seeing the import errors with the change to using the internal `mock` library.  The library needs to now reference `unittest.mock` instead.

h/t to @vrajmohan for catching this, thank you!  It is also still unclear why the Travis builds have not caught this issue either.

The view collects rows from `disclosure.f_rpt_or_form_sub` and `disclosure.nml_form_rfai`. I'm not sure I understand why. All RFAIs exist in `disclosure.f_rpt_or_form_sub`.  If we need additional information about RFAIs from `disclosure.nml_form_rfai` then we should exclude `FRQ`s from the `disclosure.f_rpt_or_form_sub` part of the script. 

select * from public.ofec_filings_mv where sub_id = 1070620170035525494;
returns two rows

select * from DISCLOSURE.NML_FORM_RFAI where sub_id = 1070620170035525494;
returns one row

select * from DISCLOSURE.F_RPT_OR_FORM_SUB where sub_id = 1070620170035525494;
returns one row
form_tp in this table is `FRQ`

title: Force using Trusty and PostgreSQL 9.6 in Travis CI
body:
We are running into some issues with our tests failing in Travis and currently all signs point to something breaking down in the Travis build.  This changeset forces the build environment to use Trusty (which Travis is in the process of rolling out to all builds regardless), which in turn also supports using PostgreSQL 9.6 (which this project is running on).  We will continue making adjustments as necessary to see what is causing the tests to fail and what might be needed to get them to work.

This PR also pins all of our development dependencies to specific versions.  Please see issue #2573 for more information.

title: Fix itemized retry script
body: This was the cause of the issue that we were seeing with delays and updates. We would like a retry feature because with the current combinations of tables and views we are drawing from, there are always going to be some transactions we have to check back on.

title: Upgrade Celery and related dependencies
body:
We've been having a few issues with the downloads recently and have pinned down the issue to be a couple of things:

* Not enough disk space allocated in the Celery apps that support downloads
* Out of date dependencies

We need to upgrade Celery and its related dependencies and allocate more disk space to the apps to provide an immediate fix to the problem.  A more long-term solution would be looking into writing download output directly to the S3 buckets if possible (this would be a separate issue).

**NOTE**

We have already allocated more disk space to the Celery apps in the interim, but we did so manually.  The upcoming PR #2471 makes this a permanent change by updating the manifest file(s).

title: Doubled numbers in candidate totals endpoint
body:
This is an issue that we had some time ago and appears to be back. It looks like any candidate that has an off-year election and then files for the next regular elections is being doubled.

Example - Greg Gianforte, in Montana:
https://www.fec.gov/data/candidate/H8MT01182/?cycle=2018&election_full=False
Total receipts should be 4880918.47 NOT 9761836.94

The problem is here:
SELECT link.cand_id AS candidate_id,
            max(election.cand_election_year) AS election_year,
            totals.cycle,
            false AS is_election,
            sum(totals.receipts) AS receipts,
            sum(totals.disbursements) AS disbursements,
            sum(totals.receipts) > 0::numeric AS has_raised_funds,
            sum(totals.last_cash_on_hand_end_period) AS cash_on_hand_end_period,
            sum(totals.last_debts_owed_by_committee) AS debts_owed_by_committee,
            min(totals.coverage_start_date) AS coverage_start_date,
            max(totals.coverage_end_date) AS coverage_end_date,
            array_agg(totals.federal_funds_flag) @> ARRAY[true] AS federal_funds_flag
           FROM **ofec_cand_cmte_linkage_mv l**ink
             JOIN totals ON link.cmte_id::text = totals.committee_id::text AND link.fec_election_yr = totals.cycle::numeric
             LEFT JOIN ofec_candidate_election_mv election ON link.cand_id::text = election.candidate_id::text AND totals.cycle <= election.cand_election_year AND totals.cycle > election.prev_election_year
          WHERE link.cmte_dsgn::text = ANY (ARRAY['P'::character varying, 'A'::character varying]::text[])
          GROUP BY link.cand_id, totals.cycle

Candidates that run in off years often end up with two rows with the same fec_election_yr one (for example) where the cand_election_yr=2017 and one where it =2018 (after they file for the next election)
Like this:
select * from   ofec_cand_cmte_linkage_mv
where cand_id='H8MT01182';

So it's doubling the totals.

title: [MERGE WITH GIT FLOW] Fix itemized schedule trigger errors
body:
**MERGE WITH GIT FLOW**

**NOTE:**  Requires running `update_itemized` (for `a` and `b`), which may require additional work as those will wipe out the existing schedule A and B queues.

Part of #2390

This changeset addresses an issue we are currently having with our itemized schedule triggers.  The triggers are setup to select rows from views currently, but they often run into a situation where the selection statement actually returns an empty resultset.  This in turn causes what amounts to an empty record (excluding what we ourselves add) being added to the itemized schedule queues to be processed later, only to fail because of trying to insert records that do not comply with table constraints (e.g., inserting a `NULL` value into a primary key column).

This puts us in a state of having to perpetually refresh data manually, which requires repartitioning the itemized schedule tables.  There is more work to be done to fix the root cause(s) of this problem, but this will at least prevent errors in our nightly refresh process for the time being.

I have also fixed a couple of issues with the integration tests in this.

**NOTE:** This now includes the index fixes @LindsayYoung worked on so they all go in together without necessitating multiple hot fixes.

title: Interim fix for the nightly itemized schedule updates
body:
@LindsayYoung and I were discussing the impact of the nightly updates routinely failing and putting us in a perpetual state of requiring partitioning of the itemized schedule A and B data, and we came to the realization that there is a solution for a stop-gap fix until we're able to address the root cause of the issue (detailed in issues #2309 and #2227; we have a meeting setup with FEC folks next week).

The idea here is that we check for the presence of an empty recordset from the view before we process it and populate it in the designated queue tables.  [PostgreSQL provides a way to check for this easily](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/plpgsql-statements.html#PLPGSQL-STATEMENTS-DIAGNOSTICS), so we'll implement a hot fix to address it and at least get our nightly updates cleaned up now.

There's an additional task that we can do as a separate hot fix to keep track of which `sub_id`s fall into this state in a separate table and retry them at another time (e.g., a day later).  They'd remain in this table until the record is successfully processed, and it'll give us a bit more of a window into which records are falling into this state so we can understand why better.  Is it an expected thing (e.g., they don't exist in the corresponding `disclosure.f_item_receipt_or_exp` table) or something else?  It'll provide us with information to go on.

To recap:

* [x] Fix the nightly updates of itemized data by checking for empty resultsets before processing (#2392)
* [x] Add support for keeping track of and retrying failed `sub_id`s (#2398)

title: Investigate issue with itemized schedule queues not being processed
body:
Since moving and deploying fully to GovCloud, we are noticing issues in the cloud.gov logs around the nightly update processing of the itemized schedule data.  The updates are actually failing behind the scenes because the process is reporting errors when processing the queue tables (records with `null` values, including in the `sub_id` field, which is the primary key and doesn't allow `null` values!).

One problem with this is that our logging and email reports isn't providing enough information, but that is already in the works to be fixed in #2306.  The remaining issue is with why this is happening with the data in the first place and why the queue processing is still failing.

title: Fix queue processing to account for column type mis-match
body:
Fixes #2286 

This changeset addresses a few remaining issues with the SQL that references the queue tables and not accounting for the `unknown` type of the `schedule_type` column.  It also addresses the `refresh_child()` method in the partitioning for the same problem.  The previous work done to fix this issue did not take into account the nightly refresh component of the partition code, only the creation of the partitions.

Additional notes have been added to some of the comments as well to explain the purpose and usage of some methods as well.

title: Fix update_all processing
body:
Fixes #2286 

This changeset addresses a couple of other issues that have cropped up with the processing in our `update_all` script.  There are two known issues thus far:

* An error while processing the new database connection strings, likely caused by unescaped/unquoted strings
* An error while processing one of the materialized views in which a column being referenced is not found

More items will be added as they are found until the script runs successfully again.  In addition to fixing these issues, this changeset also adds a few more logging statements to provide visibility into the state of things while running the command.

title: Fix update_all processing
body:
Our `update_all` script is still not running at the moment and currently encountering two issues while processing:

* An execution error when attempting to run a subprocess, likely due to an unquoted/unescaped shell command.
* A database error: `sqlalchemy.exc.ProgrammingError: (psycopg2.ProgrammingError) column ofec_totals_house_senate_mv.last_debts_owed_to_committee does not exist`

These (and any other issues) need to be addressed ASAP so that we can properly refresh the new GovCloud database instances.

title: Allow more complex parsing of citations in AOs
body:
Find examples of citations that were not identified:

Identify citations even when they are not preceded by telltale markers like "U.S.C.", e,g., 
"18 U.S.C. §§610, 611, 613, 614 and 615". In this case we should identify 611, 613, 614 and 615.

In other cases, citations may be elided as in "18 U.S.C. §§610-615". In this case we should identify 610, 611, 612, 613, 614 and 615.

- [x] !! Figure out why AO's after 2017 aren't showing citations  - missing OCR text. Checking with Salient. https://www.fec.gov/data/legal/advisory-opinions/2017-01/
- [X] Find examples of missed citations: Regulatory and Statutory. Final opinions only.
- [X] Add tests 
- [X] Look for examples of multiples for MURs - I think this is ok, as it uses the database

### Background:
AOs, current MURs, and archived MURs all have different REGEX and data sources for regulations.

- AOs use OCR text in the `aouser.document` table that is currently missing for 23 AOs. AOs cite Statutes, Regulations, and other AOs using [REGEX here](https://github.com/fecgov/openFEC/blob/develop/webservices/legal_docs/advisory_opinions.py#L69-L76)
- Current MURs have a database of citations in `fecmur.violations.regulatory_citation` and uses [REGEX here](https://github.com/fecgov/openFEC/blob/develop/webservices/legal_docs/current_murs.py#L117-L119)
- Archived MURs were OCR'd by FEC and uses [REGEX here](https://github.com/fecgov/openFEC/blob/develop/webservices/legal_docs/load_legal_docs.py#L316-L340)

title: Senate candidate and committee number problem
body:
I;ve figured out the problem with the summary figures for Senate candidates and committees. Paper amendment filers often leave null any value that doesn't change from the previous filing. In FECP we handle this in the load process into the v_sum table where an amendment null value doesn't replace the previous reports non-null value so v_sum has all of the amounts. For example, Senate committee C00473371 has 11 as-amended reports in both systems:
Beta TR     -------- V_sum TR
7961.51    -------- 7961
71677       -------- 71677
42268.29- -------- 42268
360494.12 -------- 360494
null ----------------190436
null-----------------312484
377038.89 -------- 377038
null            -------- 389451
null            -------- 519515
553648.58 -------- 553648
null            -------- 118382

The only solution I see is to feed the reports end point from v_sum.

title: Fixes update_all and underlying SQL
body:
Part of #2196 

This changeset addresses a couple of remaining table/view renames that we had to account for with the last round of database updates.  The references to the schedule A and schedule B views have been updated as has the test subset data and partitioning code.

The changes in here also modify the behavior of the queue tables that are associated with the Schedule A and B updates.  The triggers that are associated with these tables now make use of `BEFORE` and `AFTER` triggers to account for record changes in the underlying source tables because we are now relying on traditional views to derive our `ofec_sched_x` tables from.  These views contain the data represented in a structure that we can easily process, but they are comprised of multiple source tables.

In order to accomplish this, we watch for changes on one of the source tables that contains the actual record we're concerned about, then reference how the record appears in the view so that we can account for data pulled in via joins with the other source tables.  Due to this setup, we need to make sure we capture the state of the view at the right moment depending on the operation.  In other words:

* **FOR INSERTS:** We need to capture the view as it appears `AFTER` a new record is inserted.
* **FOR DELETES:** We need to capture the view as it appears `BEFORE` a record is deleted.
* **FOR UPDATES:** We need to capture the view as it appears `BEFORE` and `AFTER` a record is updated.

In the case of updates, this means that we watch for those changes in both triggers we have setup.  For the `BEFORE` trigger, we add the existing record information prior to the update to the old queue table.  For the `AFTER` trigger, the record has now been updated so we capture the record information from the view after the update to add it into the new queue.  This ensures our processing continues to work as it did before.

A **HUGE** thanks to @jontours and @LindsayYoung for talking through the approach and validating it with me!

Additional notes:

* [Triggers on Views](https://www.depesz.com/2010/10/16/waiting-for-9-1-triggers-on-views/)
* [PostgreSQL Trigger documentation](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/static/sql-createtrigger.html)

title: Fix nightly update and database refresh tasks
body:
We've recently run into a few issues with our nightly update tasks as well as the full-fledged refresh tasks and the underlying SQL scripts that power them, largely due to table name changes but also because of a few other reasons.

First, a few tables need to have their names adjusted and have `vw` attached to the end:

* `fec_vsum_sched_a`
* `fec_vsum_sched_b`
* Possibly a few others related to `fec_vsum_*` tables

Second, the nightly updates are running into two issues.  In `dev`, it's due to a primary key violation:

```
2017-02-08 09:00:00 ERROR:manager:(psycopg2.IntegrityError) duplicate key value violates unique constraint "ofec_sched_e_tmp_pkey"
DETAIL:  Key (sub_id)=(4062120141215616440) already exists.
```

In `stage` and `prod`, it's due to missing tables:

```
2017-02-08 09:00:00 ERROR:manager:(psycopg2.ProgrammingError) relation "fec_vsum_f57_queue_old" does not exist
```

Upon looking, the `fec_vsum_f57_queue_new` table doesn't exist either, but both tables are present in `dev`.

I haven't been able to tell if there are any other underlying issues at the moment, but that's the start of them.  We need to rectify these as soon as we can so we can get the nightly refreshes working again and run `update_all` on `dev`, so I'm placing it in this sprint as a bug and something to tackle before the next release.

title: [MERGE WITH GIT FLOW] Adds support for generating new itemized child tables
body:
**MERGE WITH GIT FLOW**

Closes #2136

This changeset adds a management command to support creating new child tables to an existing partition of Schedule A and Schedule B data. It will check first before just creating the new table(s) so existing data is not wiped out.

This also includes the beginning of a test suite for the partitioning code.

I modified the existing partitioning code a bit to break out some of the underlying child table processing code and ended up having to add a new flag to a couple of those methods to account for when we're doing a full partition vs. operating against already partitioned tables.

The new command is this:

```sh
./manage.py add_itemized_partition_cycle
```

Given the current year at the time of this PR (2017), this will attempt to create the 2017 - 2018 cycle tables.  If you haven't already repartitioned they'll be added, but if you have then it will skip over them.  You can also specify a cycle and/or a range:

```sh
./manage.py add_itemized_partition_cycle -c 2014 -a 5
```

This will start attempting to create child tables for the 2013 - 2014 cycle and work its way up to the 2021 - 2022 cycle (and again, skipping tables that already exist so they're not undone and wiped out).

The testing was proving to be fairly difficult to get going but I wanted to have something given the changes I had to make.  I'm definitely open to suggestions for improvement and/or pairing with someone to take them further!

/cc @LindsayYoung, @jontours

title: Add missing 2017 - 2018 cycle tables for schedule A and B
body:
@jontours uncovered an issue in #2134 while trying to fix tests that started failing after the start of the new year, and it led both of us to realize an underlying problem:  we don't have child tables for the new, upcoming cycle of `2017 - 2018`.

I think this is doable relatively quickly and easily without needing to repartition completely unless we're missing data already, but I don't think we are (and I asked in the partners Slack channel to double check that).  In any case, here is what I believe this entails:

* Create a new management command, perhaps `add_itemized_partition_cycle` or something, and have it call the underlying `create_child` method in the partition objects directly with the specific cycle.
* Allow the user to specify a cycle, but by default have it just create one child table with the next cycle based off of last existing table and current calculated cycle (if the table already exists, then just print out a note to the user and exit the command immediately).
* Do this for both schedule A and schedule B together so they stay in sync.

Unfortunately we do need to take care of this now due to the fact that we are in 2017 and data will be coming soon.

title: Committee endpoint issue
body: An example endpoint `/v1/candidate/P80005341/committees/` is throwing a 500 error.  Ultimately the reason is that in the view `fec_vsum_f1_vw` the column `filing_form` is generated via a statement such as `filing_form = 'f1'`.  When the material views are refreshed this column gets converted to an unknown and then SqlAlchemy fails.  Altering the view `fec_vsum_f1_vw` and casting the column should resolve the problem (and then running update_schemas).

body:
As originally noted [via the feedback tool](https://github.com/18F/FEC/issues/543), we're displaying links to .fec files for RFAIs, which don't actually have them.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1696495/21058843/c897f83e-bdf4-11e6-84c8-1da0e966ad23.png)

We're checking for these URLs on the front-end and only display a link if the response is there, so I checked and it looks like [these responses](https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/filings/?api_key=5yyI90SU3Xb73TVlv4wrEhQxYcCwMWCywQiGdYbJ&sort_hide_null=true&data_type=processed&form_type=RFAI&sort=-receipt_date&per_page=30&page=1) have this broken URL in the field:
`"fec_url": "http://docquery.fec.gov/paper/posted/.fec",`

We should only include a `fec_url` property if there's a real value. 

This isn't a pressing bug, but we should address soon.

title: How to merge is_notice=false with is_notice=true with schedule_e (independent expenditures)
body:
I'm having a hard time understanding how to merge `is_notice=true`, which are the 24- and 48-hour reports, with `is_notice=false` for `schedule_e` (independent expenditures). For my understanding, I simply see `is_notice=true` as more recent, but temporary reports, whereas I see `is_notice=false` as archived and permanent reports.

Right now I pulled both types of reports (for Clinton and Trump only) and summed up the chart by expenditure amount:

![by_e](http://i.imgur.com/bAwyF8I.png)

And by count:

![by_c](http://i.imgur.com/oou485y.png)

So in order to get all the recent reports that haven't been "converted" from `is_notice=true` to `is_notice=false` then is it say to say I should take all `is_notice=false` reports from September and merge it with all `is_notice=true` from October and November (the only two months where the bar is all orange). But in reality October and November aren't completely `is_notice=true`, it's just more like 99% of it (so you can't see the blue part in the chart).

The actual last day (most recent) `is_notice=false` is November 24th, but the spending and count for `is_notice=false` for October and November is tiny compared to `is_notice=true` for those two months:

title: Statutory citations with elided sections are loaded incorrectly
body: When statutory citations specify the subsection but not the section (in which case it is a subsection of the section indicated by the previous item in a group), they are not loaded correctly by `load_current_murs`. title: Adds committee names back into itemized schedule downloads
body:
Closes #1940 

This changeset addresses #1940 by adding support for related fields back into our exports on the itemized tables.  It does this by defining an extra attribute in our schema Meta objects that is ignored by everything but our export code.  This extra attribute allows you to set additional columns that are found in nested models related to the parent model you are trying to export.  If any are defined, the export functionality will follow the relationship to pull the information out and display it in the output with the specified label.  Documentation in the schema provides more information on how to do this.

This changeset also modifies our Schedule E model by removing the `committee_name` field set directly to the `cmte_nm` field in the table.  This field can sometimes be `null`, so we should be pulling it from the related `CommitteeHistory` model instead, just like the Schedule A and B models already do.

Lastly, this also supports an option to sort the columns in the output alphabetically.  This is disabled for now, but there is support to insert these additional conditional columns into specific positions as opposed to just the end.  This is used for the new `committee_name` column added back in for this PR.

/cc @LindsayYoung and @jontours

title: Replace missing delete statements
body:
Part of #1820 

This changeset replaces the delete statements that went missing from the schedule A queue processing we have.  This has caused an issue where multiple records with the same `sub_id` might exist in these tables and therefore might result in insert errors in the main `ofec_sched_a_*` tables due to existing primary keys from records already processed.

This changeset also addresses an issue where an index being created on the `fec_vsum_sched_b` table was being duplicated due to not being dropped first.

/cc @LindsayYoung, @jontours

title: Add support for renaming indexes
body:
Part of #1838 
Fixes #1840

When partitioning the itemized Schedule A and B tables, the indexes of the existing tables were being dropped and recreated, but this impacted the existing tables before they were replaced. As partitioning these tables takes a long time with the full FEC data set, this can cause problems if the partitioning is taking place during normal usage times.  Without indexes on these tables for the columns that we expose for searching and filtering, the database performance grinds to an absolute halt and queries back up.

This changeset alleviates this issue by renaming the indexes once the tables themselves are renamed so that they are not removed too early.  The `create_index` method still attempts to drop the indexes like before, but it will only do so if they still have `_tmp` in their name.  This is to account for a situation when the partition fails to complete and the processing is left in an unfinished state.

This changeset also adds a bit of logging information around the partitioning events.

/cc @LindsayYoung, @jontours

title: rename indexes
body:
During partitioning all our indexes are being dropped and this is causing queries to be crazy slow and eat up storage space.

We want to add a function like rename tables to rename indexes, hopefully that will keep them from being dropped.

title: Schedule E aggregates don't appear to be comprehensively updated
body:
Hi guys,

I'm running into discrepancies when comparing schedule E aggregates from the FEC API to the main FEC website that I was hoping you could address. For example, the API has Restoration PAC spending $20k over 3 transactions against Hillary (https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/committee/C00571588/schedules/schedule_e/by_candidate/?page=1&api_key=DEMO_KEY&sort_nulls_large=true&candidate_id=P00003392&per_page=20
). However, when I add up the itemizations from the main FEC website (http://fec.gov/data/IndependentExpenditure.do?format=html) for that PAC against Hillary, I get 18 transactions totalling $475k. 

I've filtered out memoed items and limited the data to before 2/29/2016 across the itemized dataset in order to best approximate what the API has (although it doesn't apply in the case of Restoration PAC). Interestingly enough, when I apply that same filtering methodology to some PACs spending in support of Hillary (i.e. Priorities USA Action) the numbers exactly match. It seems pretty hit or miss across the full API dataset concerning Hillary though - I've only found a few committees that exactly match.

I dug into the itemizations to learn more and saw that Restoration PAC had 3 transactions of $20k total only through December 31, 2015, which leads me to believe that while Priorities USA was updated through 2/29, some other committees were not for some reason. Can you please confirm if that's the case, or if I'm doing something wrong in my analysis?

Thanks!
Corby

I've attached the itemized file I downloaded from the main site below:

[independent-expenditure.xlsx](https://github.com/18F/openFEC/files/192203/independent-expenditure.xlsx)

title: Sanders DC totals don't match totals on fec.gov presidential map
body:
I think this came from the beta feedback system. The pres map only has about $212,000 for Sanders from DC. The beta site has over $10,000,000. The problem is Sanders is reporting a single transaction for UNITEMIZED TOTAL contributions and has it listed as being from DC.  This isn't uncommon. Most places where it would cause a problem we filter out contributions where the upper contributor name contains "UNITEM". 

HIllary does this too. Others may as well.

title: elections summary missing consistent "results: : [ ] formatting
body:
I just noticed this:
`https://api.open.fec.gov/v1/elections/summary/?office=president&api_key=DEMO_KEY`
returns

}

title: Bug: "Palouse Says Enough" listed as a principal committee for Bernie Sanders
body:
Cross-posted from https://github.com/18F/openFEC/issues/1304#issuecomment-151236236:

A committee named "Palouse Says Enough" is listed as one of Bernie Sanders's principal committees in `dimlinkages`. @jwchumley and @PaulClark2, can you look into why this committee is showing up as one of Sanders's principal committees? I'm wondering if this is another issue that will be resolved for free when as we move away from the DW--it looks like the data are incorrect in `dimlinkages`, but hopefully they're correct in whatever the FECP equivalent of that table is. If that's the case, there's no need to investigate the issue in `dimlinkages`--we can just push over the FECP table and go from there.

fec=> select cmte_tp, cmte_dsgn, * from dimlinkages where cand_id = 'P60007168' and cmte_id = 'C00589432';

title: Some totals variables are too high
body: A handful of year-to-date and period-to-date variables from reports are being summed in our totals views, leading to large overestimates of those values. Examples include net receipts and net operating expenditures. These values don't show up on the webapp but are available through the API.

title: Sorting not really supported
body:
On the committee and candidate list tables we have in-browser sorting but that doesn't really sort all the results most of the time, there are results being paginated in the API.

I propose we disable the sorting feature until we complete #176 (or a new issue that accounts for making the API sortable by categories of the user's choice)

title: Committee start date issue

milestone.title: Sprint 14b: Mr. Owl, the tootsie pop owl

body:
One of the things I am looping back on now is using the `committee_origination_ date` in `create_committee_view.sql` and `create_committe_view` we are using the most recent load date, when we would want the oldest load date for that committee in dimcmteproperties. `` and start date of the committee.

In theory, they should be giving us the `committee_origination_ date` in `dimcmteproperties` now. Is this something you can see in Golden Gate @jmcarp? (The older version of the data we got from the vpn had that column with nothing populated so we were calculating it ourselves.)

If we keep using the wrong origination date, the result filtering by year will be incorrect.

title: Dropdowns for candidate profiles are not working
body:
For now, I think it would be good to just display the most recent year and hide the drop down for now, since that is the year that the page is displaying. 

We can implement the dropdown menu later, that is #323

example:

http://api.open.fec.gov/committee/C00543637/totals?api_key=xxx

(My guess is that the names changed since we last did documentation that this work was modeled off of.)

title: Cash and Debt dates
body:
Cash and Debt  are numbers from a point in time. 

Underneath those stats in the horizontal bar chart list, we want something like "Reported in 2013 Termination Report"

For the cash and debt chart, we are using the number that is reported at the end of the period, so we want just the end date under those figures.

title: New Relic Config Tweaks
body:
New Relic is currently showing two apps, neither of which seem to be correctly reporting... We need to make sure that:
- [ ] The web and API apps are clearly named in New Relic config
- [ ] The different environments (dev/stage/prod) of each are also clearly delineated
- [ ] Each environment is reporting correctly:
  - [ ] dev-api
  - [ ] dev-web
  - [ ] stage-api
  - [ ] stage-web
  - [ ] prod-api
  - [ ] prod-web
- [ ] Any cruft is cleaned up (if applicable) in the NR dashboard

title: Pagination Seems to Fail
body:
This is a weird sporadic issue that I didn't see logged anywhere else, please feel free to close/ignore if I missed it.

The `/candidates`, `/search/`, and the `/committees` endpoints seem to fail when doing any pagination or querying, or when selecting certain types or even having different individual terms. For instance:

`/committees`: works as expected
`/committees?page=2` works as expected
`/committees?page=3` fails
`/?search=the` works, returns no results
`/?search=obama` works
`/candidates?q=obama` works
`/candidates?q=clinton` fails
`/committee/C00494740` fails
`/candidate/P80003338` works

Is there a trace of these results logged so that I can try and debug?

title: No year filter on single resources
body:
We are using year defaults on singular and plural endpoints. It makes sense to filter multiple resources to a manageable default but not the singe resource endpoints, since the user is specifying that particular resource. 

For instance you can see  /committee/C00202176/?year=\* but not /committee/C00202176

title: Empty committee result set that should be filled
body:
A committee is returning both totals and reports but the actual committee is returning empty.

Reproduction:
On both my localhost database, and on staging site:
`GET /committee/C00000422/reports` returns a full result set
`GET /committee/C00000422/totals` returns a full result set
`GET /committee/C00000422` returns an empty result set.

Expected:
I would expect `GET /committee/C00000422` to return a full result set with committee information such as name, etc.

May potentially be blocking me from completing #560 as I will need the correct data for it.

title: Messages other than 500 when committee reports are not found
body:
Right now the front end throws a 500 error on the committee page when committees have no reports. It should either say that we found no data or that we have not loaded the data for that committee yet.

Since we are only showing reports for certain committee_types if it is of a committee_type that we have not loaded the data for, we were going to link back to the fec website. 

For committee_type H, S, P, N, V, W, X, Y, Z if they have filed reports, they should show up.

@noahmanger This is what we said at one of the backlog meetings, correct?

title: CF needs migrations
body:
The API in cloud foundry needs to run migration to get the tables it needs. 

example:
`http://fec-api-dev.cf.18f.us/candidate/H4UT04052`
produces:

```
sqlalchemy.exc.ProgrammingError: (ProgrammingError) column ofec_candidate_detail_vw.candidate_expire_date does not exist
LINE 2: FROM (SELECT ofec_candidate_detail_vw.candidate_expire_date ...
```

I tried launching the app with a shell script that runs the migration and then the api, but the migrations seemed to error out. Maybe it is permissions? 

Task:
- [ ] get `python manage.py refresh_db` to run successfully on cloudfoundry before starting the app

title: calling API with bad filter parameters should raise error
body:
Currently the API silently ignores filter parameters it does not recognize.  This causes confusion like in issue #154.

The API should throw a clear error when an unrecognized filter parameter is passed.

Goal: Obey the Principle of Least Surprise
Criteria for completion: Call API with bogus argument.  Clear error should result
Dependencies: none (flask_restful team has already signalled willingness to accept patch)
User need: don't waste time being confused by silent failures
Steps:
- Fork flask_restful
- Add check for bad parameter to flask_restful
- Submit test & code upstream (but use fork until it's incorporated)
- Ensure that API gives good error message when flask_restful throws the exception
